case_title: PUSPA DEVI vs COMMISSIONER OF INCOME-TAX

accussed_details.name: Puspa Devi
allegation: Income arising to minor sons from partnership benefits assessed under section 64(1)(iii) of Income Tax Act, 1961.

complaint_summary: The Assessing Officer sought to include income arising to the minor sons of the assessee from their admission to the benefits of a partnership firm in the assessee's total income under section 64(1)(iii) of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
investigation_summary: The Assessing Officer initiated action under section 148 of the Income Tax Act for assessment years 1976-77, 1977-78, and 1978-79. The assessee contended that she had no income of her own to which the minors' income could be added. This contention was rejected by the Assessing Officer but accepted by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner. The Income Tax Tribunal upheld the Assessing Officer's view.
judgment_summary: The court held that the income arising to the minor sons of the assessee from their admission to the benefits of a partnership firm is liable to be included and assessed in the hands of the assessee under section 64(1)(iii) of the Income Tax Act, 1961, even if the assessee has no income of her own from any source.
Decision_or_verdict: Reference answered in favor of the Revenue.
legal_arguments: Section 64(1)(iii) of the Income Tax Act, 1961 mandates inclusion of income arising to minor children admitted to partnership benefits in the total income of the parent.
The assessee argued that absence of her own income precludes application of section 64(1)(iii).
The court rejected this argument, citing precedents from Andhra Pradesh, Karnataka, Patna, Orissa, and Madhya Pradesh High Courts.
citations: CIT v. G. Gopal Rao (1985) 151 ITR 308
Additional CIT v. H.L. Gulati (1982) 138 ITR 648
key_issues: Whether income arising to minor sons admitted to partnership benefits can be assessed in the hands of the parent under section 64(1)(iii) of the Income Tax Act, 1961.

legal_terms.Total Income: Defined under section 2(45) of the Income Tax Act, 1961.
legal_terms.Partnership Benefits: Income arising to minors admitted to partnership benefits.

words_and_phrases.Admission to Benefits of Partnership: Inclusion of minors in partnership profits without being partners.

summary_vector_notes: The judgment clarifies the application of section 64(1)(iii) of the Income Tax Act, 1961, emphasizing that income arising to minor children admitted to partnership benefits is includible in the parent's total income, irrespective of the parent's own income status. The court relied on precedents from multiple High Courts to reject the assessee's contention.
